April 1922.CONFIDENTIAL.CP. 3931.CABINET.CONSTABULARY (IRELAND) BILL.Memorandum by the Chief Secretary fob Ireland. (Circulated to the Committee of Home Affairs.)I CIRCULATE herewith the draft of a Bill which has been prepared to make provision for the disbandment of the Royal Irish Constabulary and with respect to magistrates appointed under the Acts relating to that force, and for the validation of things done or omitted in the execution or purported execution of those Acts, and for other purposes incidental thereto.The sole object of this Bill is to give legal effect, so far as is necessary, to the terms on which the Government have undertaken to disband the Royal Irish Constabulary. Disbandment is, in fact, taking place on these terms at the present time, but it is most important that this Bill should be passed into law as soon as possible, as until this is done there will be great difficulty in administering that part of the disbandment scheme which has reference to the commutation of compensation allowance in cases where a man desires to emigrate.The Bill has been drafted in close consultation and agreement with the Treasury. 1 hope, therefore, that I. may be given permission to introduce the Bill forthwith.H.
